analytic.title: Advances in Engineering Software

biblStruct.note: Received 9 October 2018; Received in revised form 30 January 2019; Accepted 9 March 2019 ‚Åé Corresponding author.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Concrete gravity dams Structural health monitoring Long term air temperature effect (Least-squares) support vector machines Jaya optimization Salp swarm algorithms

div.p: This paper presents innovative algorithms combining Jaya optimizer, salp swarm algorithms and (least-squares) support vector machines for simulating the temperature effect accurately in dam health monitoring modeling. The temperature effect is simulated by different variable sets of air temperature to get a reasonable choice. The proposed long-term air temperature based support vector machines algorithms are verified on monitoring data of a concrete gravity dam. Results confirm the ability of the proposed hybrid strategies to efficiently mine the effect of air temperature on dam behavior. The proposed approach based on direct air temperature observation can result in significant reduction in prediction errors of the dam displacements. The proposed method is tested on a concrete gravity dam and it is expected to be further tested on concrete arch dams in the future.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Dams are important structures in a reservoir project for water control, navigation and hydroelectric power generation, etc. Failure of dams can cause disastrous consequences to the personal properties and ecological environment in the downstream. Dam health monitoring systems provide an effective way for dam safety evaluation in real time. The observed structural responses, like displacements, are compared with predicted values obtained by mathematical models to identify whether the behavior of the structure is still reasonable. If the divergence between the measured value and the model prediction is larger than an early warning threshold, the reason for the change should be identified to prevent disaster occurs [1,2].

Statistical models based on multiple linear regression and their advanced forms have been shown to be more or less successful in dam health monitoring modeling [3]. The adopted regression models include the multiple linear regression (MLR) [1], the stepwise regression (SR) [4,5], the principal component analysis based regression model [6,7], the partial least-squares regression [8] etc. Recently, some machine learning techniques like artificial neural networks [9][10][11], neurofuzzy systems [12,13], support vector machines [14][15][16], boosted regression trees [17], extreme learning machines [5], etc. are also introduced to solve dam health monitoring problems. More extensive review of the topic is given in the work of Bukenya et al. [18] and Salazar [19,20]. The limitations of these models are hard for model structures and parameters selection. Meanwhile, previous dam health monitoring models are mostly developed from the HST (hydrostatic, season, time) model, which simulates the temperature effect by harmonic sinusoidal functions. The model is convenient, but it cannot reflect the effect of temperature variations in different years to the studied dam responses.

It is an intuition to simulate the thermal effect using measured air and/or dam body temperature [4,5,7,13,[21][22][23][24][25][26][27] and HTT (hydrostatic, temperature, time) models are proposed. Leger and Leclerc [21] presented frequency domain solution procedures for developing the HTT statistical model to interpret recorded pendulum displacements of concrete dams. Mata et al. [7] proposed a HT PCA T model using temperatures of the dam body directly and principal component analysis (PCA) is adopted to find statistically significant temperature observations for the proposed functional model. Numerical results show that the proposed HT PCA T model performs better than HST models. Except to use dam temperature, several scholars have tried to consider the thermal effect using air temperature [4,5,13,[22][23][24][25][26][27], since the structure temperature is strongly correlated to the air temperature. Mata et al. [22] proposed frequency domain techniques for analyzing the effect of the daily variation of the air temperature on the structural response of a concrete dam. Tatin et al. [23,24] developed a hybrid physico-statistical HSTT (Thermal HST) model by introducing the air temperature and water temperature to improve the assessment of displacements due to the temperature field in a dam. Data-driven models using measured segmented air temperature data are also developed [4,5,13,[25][26][27] considering the lag effect between the internal temperature and the external temperature changes. This type of model has achieved several successful applications, but the suitable length of air temperature data needs further discussion. The time period of air temperature is extended to several years and long-term air temperature based HT A T (hydrostatic, air temperature, time) model is proposed to obtain more accurate dam behavior prediction.

To mine the thermal effect from long-term measured air temperature, the traditional linear regression models are not qualified considering they are not well-suited to model nonlinear interactions between input variables. More flexible methods have to be introduced for establishing the prediction model. In this study, intelligent machine learning approaches based on support vector machines (SVM) [28] and least squares support vector machines (LSSVM) [29] are proposed to solve the problem. Support vector machines developed by Vapnik [28] are powerful and robust methodology firmly grounded in the framework of statistical learning theory. Originally, SVM was developed to solve classification problems. Then it was extended to solve nonlinear regression problems, and this technique is known as support vector regression [30]. The SVM model showed excellent performance in various prediction fields, such as flood forecasting [31], electric load forecasting [32], geotechnical reliability analysis [33,34] etc. LSSVM is introduced by Suykens et al. [29] as a variation of the conventional support vector machines. LSSVM not only has the same advantages of SVM, such as retaining the principle of SVM and having good generalization capability, but also has additional advantages over the SVM method like fast training. The LSSVM model also showed excellent performance in various prediction fields, and gained more and more popularity for engineering forecasting problems [35,36]. Meanwhile, estimation accuracy of SVM and LSSVM depends on a proper setting of hyper-parameters, and there is no general consensus on the appropriate setting of these parameters.

Nature-inspired meta-heuristic optimization algorithms are widely adopted for various science and engineering problems. The population based heuristic algorithms have two dominant groups: evolutionary algorithms and swarm intelligence based algorithms. Evolutionary algorithms are inspired by the laws of natural evolution. The well-known evolutionary algorithms [37] are genetic algorithms, genetic programming, differential evolution, etc. Swarm intelligence algorithms imitate the intelligence of swarms, herds, schools, or flocks of creatures in nature. The most popular swarm-based techniques [37] are ant colony optimization, particle swarm optimization, artificial bee colony algorithm, etc. Other swarm intelligence algorithms include grey wolf optimization [38], ant lion optimizer [39], whale optimization algorithms [40], grasshopper optimization algorithm [41], etc. Besides the evolutionary and swarm intelligence based algorithms, there are also some other algorithms which work on the principles of different natural phenomena [37]. These techniques are generally probabilistic algorithms and require common controlling parameters like population size, number of generations, etc. Besides the common control parameters, most of these algorithms require their own algorithm-specific control parameters. The proper tuning of the algorithm-specific parameters is a very crucial factor which affects the algorithm performance. The improper tuning of algorithm-specific parameters either increases the computational effort or yields the local optimal solution [37]. Jaya algorithm [37,[42][43][44] is a novel global optimization technique that was proposed without any algorithm specific parameter to be turned. Meanwhile, Jaya has only one update equation. These characteristics make the algorithm to be simple and easy to implement. It has been shown that Jaya algorithm is efficient in solving the benchmark optimization problems [37,42] and some real world problems [43,44]. Salp swarm algorithm (SSA) [45] is another recently proposed meta-heuristic algorithm for global optimization. SSA also does not contain any algorithm-specific parameter to be tuned, which makes the algorithm convenient to implement. Meanwhile, SSA has many unique characteristics that make it favorable to be utilized as the search engine in global optimization problems [46]. Therefore, an attempt is made in this work to apply Jaya and SSA algorithms to select the parameters of SVM and LSSVM, and hybrid models are proposed for the behavior prediction of concrete dams.

The paper discusses an up-to-date question in dam structural safety procedures: to incorporate measured (air) temperatures directly into the model instead of using a model with indirect modeling of the temperature influence by harmonic sinusoidal functions. The performance of the proposed HT A T model using long-term air temperature and (least-squares) support vector machines is tested on a concrete gravity dam. Promising results are obtained for the studied example and similar results are expected for concrete arch dams.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, dam health monitoring modeling problem is stated. In Section 3, long-term air temperature based SVM and LSSVM model are presented. Simulation results are presented in Section 4, and in Section 5, conclusions are provided.

div.head: Dam health monitoring modeling
div.p: Data obtained from static health monitoring system are generally analyzed by using statistical models based on correlations between environmental factors and dam responses. Environmental factors include reservoir water levels, temperatures consist of the dam internal temperature and external temperatures of air and reservoir, earthquakes, etc., and the responses refer to displacements, uplift pressures, seepage, crack, stress and strain etc. The actual response of the dam is compared with the predictions of the mathematical model, with the aim of detecting anomalies and preventing failures [19]. The dam displacement is an overall index of the dam integrity. Therefore, the model for displacement monitoring is discussed in the following study.

Various statistical models have been proposed for the analysis of monitoring data [47]. The response of the dam is separated by two parts, (a) reversible effects due to hydrostatic load and temperature, and (b) irreversible effects induced by creep, alkali aggregation reaction and other damages. The HST model is the most common statistical model for safety control of concrete dams. A general statistical model is adopted to analyze the response of an instrument and can be formulated as follows:
div.formula: = + + + y y y y i h T t (1)
div.p: where y i is the measured horizontal displacements of the ith dam section, y h is the response due to the hydrostatic load, y T is the response due to temperature changes, y t is the irreversible time effects, and Œµ is the residual/difference between modeled/predicted and measured values of displacement.
According to theoretical analysis, the three components of the displacement can be expressed as follows [1,21,22,48,49]:
div.formula: = + + + y a a h a h a h h 0 1 1 2 23 3
= + + + + y b b s b s b s b s s sin( ) cos( ) sin ( ) sin( )cos( ) T 0 1 2 3 24
= + + y c c c e or t 01 2
div.p: where h is the upstream water level or water depth; s = 2œÄj/365.25, j is the number of days from the beginning of the year (January 1) to the data of observation; sin(s), cos(s), sin 2 (s) and sin(s)cos(s) are combinations of harmonic sinusoidal functions use to simulate periodic evolution of the dam response to seasonal phenomena of temperature; Œ∏ = t/100 [50], t is number of days since the beginning of the analysis; and a j (j = 0,1,‚Ä¶,3), b j (j = 0,1,‚Ä¶,4) and c j (j = 0,1,2) are unknown coefficients.

Although exponential functions and logarithmic functions can be used to represent the evolution of time effect at the early age, a linear function of time is preferred for a dam running many years [23]. The time effects can be expressed as y t = c 0 + c 1 Œ∏. For concrete dams that have been in operation for many years, the internal temperature can be regarded as quasi-steady state, and the temperature of the dam is generally not recorded enough. The dam response to seasonal phenomena of temperature is assumed to follow periodic evolution. The temperature effect can be calculated as a combination of harmonic sinusoidal functions as Eq. ( 3).

Except to consider the temperature effect in a seasonal form, it can also be evaluated by real measured air/dam temperature data [5,7,[21][22][23][24][25]. For example, the relationship between temperature effect y T and segmented air temperature T p-q can be presented as [5,25]
div.formula: = + + + + + y b b T b T b T b T b T T 0 1
= + + + + + y b b T b T b T b T b T T 0 1(6)
div.p: where T 0 represents the mean daily air temperature of the measured day, T p-q represents the average air temperatures in the p to q days before the observation date of the dam response.

div.head: Air temperature based hybrid models for dam health monitoring
Support vector machines
div.p: Given a data set {(x i , y i ), i = 1, ‚Ä¶, N}, where x i is a D-dimensional input vector, and y i is a scalar output or target, N is the number of points. The nonlinear relationship between the input and the output can be described by a regression function as [28,29]
where f(x) denotes the forecasting values, œï(x) is a nonlinear mapping function, and w and b are the coefficients to be adjusted.
The commonly used regression model based on support vector machines is called Œµ-support vector regression [30]. The primal optimization problem for support vector regression can be defined as

div.head: Least squares support vector machines
div.p: Compared with the standard support vector machines, least-squares support vector machines apply linear least squares criteria for the loss function instead of inequality constraints with equality ones [29,35,36,[51][52][53][54]. The following optimization problem is formulated:

div.head: Parameter selection of (least-squares) support vector machines 3.3.1. Jaya algorithm
div.p: Jaya algorithm is a novel population-based global optimization algorithm proposed by Rao [37]. The algorithm is designed on the logic that any solution of the given population should always move towards the best solution and move away from the worst solution. The advantage of this algorithm is that it contains only one equation and it does not contain any algorithm-specific parameters to be tuned to get optimal solution [44]. Therefore, it is easy to understand and uniquely different from other meta-heuristic algorithms. The mathematical description of Jaya algorithm is as follows. Let f(u) be the objective function to be optimized. At the initial stage, some solutions {u 1 , u 2 ,‚Ä¶, u m } are randomly generated in the search domain, where m is the population size. These initial solutions are evaluated by the objective function, and the best solution u best and the worst solution u worst is founded. Then, these solutions perform cycle by cycle search, until the maximum generation or the optimization goal is achieved. At any iteration i, a solution of the population is modified as follows:
div.formula: = + v u r u u r u u ( ) ( ) j k j k j j best j k j j worst j k , ,1, , , 2, , ,
div.p: where u j,best is the value of the variable j for the best candidate and u j,worst is the value of the variable j for the worst candidate. v j,k is the updated value of u j,k , and r 1,j and r 2,j are two random numbers for the jth variable during the ith iteration in the range [0, 1]. The term r 1,j ((u j,best -|u j,k |) indicates the tendency of the solution to move closer to the best solution, and the term -r 2,j (u j,worst -|u j,k |) indicates the tendency of the solution to avoid the worst solution. The random numbers r 1 and r 2 ensure good exploration of the search space. The absolute value of the candidate solution (|u j,k |) considered in Eq. ( 24) further enhances the exploration ability of the algorithm. The generated new solution will be evaluated by the objective function. If the new solution is better than the original solution, replace the old solution with the new one. Else, keep the original solution as it is. That means v j,k is accepted if it gives a better function value. All the accepted solutions at the end of the iteration are maintained and further searches are performed based on these solutions in the next iteration. In the proposed algorithm, the solution obtained for a given problem is moving towards the best solution and avoiding the worst solution. Fig. 2 shows the flowchart of the Jaya algorithm.

div.head: Salp swarm algorithm
div.p: Salp swarm algorithm [45] is a swarm intelligence based global optimization algorithm inspired by the navigation and foraging behaviors of salp swarms. The salps are barrel-shaped, free floating tunicates from the family of Salpidae [46]. In oceans, salps often float together as a salp chain as shown in Fig. 3. Some researchers believe that this manner can achieve better locomotion and foraging.

The salp chain behavior has been modeled mathematically by dividing the population into two groups: leaders and followers. The leaders guide the swarm, and the followers follow each other. The target of the swarm is a food source called F in the search space. Similar to other swarm intelligence algorithms, an initial population is generated by initializing a predefined number of individuals with random positions in the search domain. The solutions can represented as {u 1 , u 2 ,‚Ä¶, u m }, where m is the population size. Afterward, these salps update their positions in two phases. The leader position is updated as follows: where u j 1 is the position of the leader in the jth dimension, F j is the position of the food source in the jth dimension, ub j and lb j are the are the upper and lower bounds of jth dimension, c 2 and c 3 are random numbers uniformly generated in the interval
div.formula: [0 1]. c 1 is a coefficient calculated as = ( ) c e 2 l L 1 4 2 (26)
div.p: where l is the current iteration and L is the maximum number of iterations. Variable c 1 is gradually decreased over the iteration process, which makes the algorithm first explores the search space and then exploits it. Actually, c 1 is the most important parameter in SSA since it balances exploration and exploitation.
For each follower salp, the position is updated as follows:
div.formula: = + u u u 1 2 ( ) j i j i j i 1(27)
div.p: where i ‚â• 2 and u j i is the position of the ith follower salp in the jth dimension.

The pseudocode of SSA is shown in Fig. 4. SSA algorithm assigns the best solution obtained so far to the food source F, so the algorithm never gets lost. The positions of the leading salps are updated respect to the food source only, so the leaders always explore and exploit the space around the best solution. The positions of follower salps are updated with respect to each other, so they move gradually towards the leading salp. The gradual movements of follower salps prevent the algorithm from easily being trapped at a local optimum. SSA also does not contain any algorithm-specific parameters to be tuned to get optimal solution. So the algorithm is simple and easy to implement.

The computational complexity of the SSA algorithm is of [45], where l is the number of iterations, d is the number of variables (dimension), m is the number of solutions, and Cof represents the cost of objective function.
div.formula: O (l √ó (d √ó m + Cof √ó m))

div.head: Jaya algorithm, SSA optimized (least-squares) support vector machines
div.p: The parameters of SVM, LSSVM to be optimized are encoded in the solutions of optimization algorithms. For SVM optimization, a solution can be represented as u = {u 1 , u 2 , u 3 }, where u 1 , u 2 , u 3 denote the parameters log 10 C, log 10 Œ≥, log 10 Œµ, respectively. For LSSVM optimization, a solution can be represented as u = {u 1 , u 2 }, where u 1 , u 2 denote the parameters log 10 C and log 10 œÉ 2 , respectively. The method of encoding gives a more stable optimization [54]. A popular way to estimate the generalization performance of a model is cross-validation described in [51]. The procedure of cross-validation divides given data randomly into S distinct subsets {G s , s = 1, ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ, S} of (approximately) equal size, and uses S-1 subsets for training, and uses the remaining one subset for validation. The process is repeated S times by changing the remaining subset.
The objective function value of solution u is calculated based on the mean squared error (MSE) of cross-validation as
div.formula: = = = u x u f MSE N y f ( ) 1 ( ( )| ) , u s S i G i i 1 1 2 s (28
div.p: where N is the number of samples for training, S is the number of subsets for cross validation, G s denote the sth subset for validation, y i is the target value, and f(x i )|u is the value predicted by LSSVM when the hyper-parameters are set as u. In this study, S is set as 10, which means 10-fold cross validation is adopted for training.

Another method to select a proper set of parameters is trial and error method. In order to avoid over-fitting, it is often necessary to observe both training and test errors. In this way, the fitting performance of the model can be guaranteed, and the generalization ability of the model is also considered. Inspired by this method, the following objective function based on weighted MSE for model parameter optimization is proposed as
div.formula: = = + = = u x u x u f MSE w N y f w M y f ( ) 1 ( ( )| ) 1 ( ( )| ) , u i N i i i M i i 2 1 1 2 2 1 2(29)
div.p: where N, M are the numbers of samples for training and test; w 1 and w 2 are the weights of training error and test error, 0 < w 1 , w 2 < 1.0, w 1 + w 2 = 1.0; y i is the target value, and f(x i )|u is the predicted value when the hyper-parameters are set as u.

In Eq. ( 29), the first part represents the weighted MSE of training samples and the second part represents the weighted MSE of test samples. Some combinations of weights (w 1 , w 2 ), such as (0.5, 0.5), (0.6, 0.4), (0.7, 0.3), (0.8, 0.2), etc. can be tested to obtain ideal fitting and generalization performances. It has to point out that, for a specific set parameter set u, the model is established by training samples. After the model is established, the test error can be calculated as in the second part of Eq. (29).
The main steps of using Jaya algorithm for parameter optimization are summarized as follows:

(1) Initialization. Randomly generate m initial solutions in the search domain. Evaluate the initial solutions by objective functions Eq. ( 28) or ( 29). (2) Find the best and worst solutions in the population.

(3) For each solution u i , generate a candidate solution v i according to Eq. ( 24), and evaluate it by cross validation. The objective function value is calculated as Eq. ( 28) or ( 29). (4) If f(v i ) < f(u i ), update u i with v i ; else, keep the solution u i unchanged. (5) Repeat steps (2)-( 4), until a termination criterion is met. (6) Output the best solution, which has the minimum value of MSE.
The procedure of using SSA for parameter optimization is summarized as follows:

(1) Initialization. Randomly generate m initial solutions in the search domain. Evaluate the initial solutions by objective functions in Eq. ( 28) or ( 29). (2) Sort the salp positions according to the fitness values.

(3) Set F as the best position of current population. (4) For each solution u i , if (i ‚â§ m/2) update the position of leading salps by Eq. ( 25), else update the position of the follower salps by Eq. ( 27). ( 5) Evaluate the objective function value of each salp as Eq. ( 28) or (29). ( 6) Repeat steps (2)-( 5), until a termination criterion is met. (7) Output the best solution.

div.head: Variable sets of long-term air temperature
div.p: Local observations of the dam structure temperature are not always available, and the structure temperature is strongly correlated to the air temperature. The study proposed a long-term air temperature based HT A T model to directly model measured air temperature and to propose an objective algorithm for estimation of unknown parameters of the used functional model.

According to experience, the highest and lowest air temperatures of adjacent two years can have a difference of five to ten degrees Celsius. Developing models which can reflect the effect of temperature variations in different years is important to make precise predictions of dam responses. The aim is making an accurate evaluation of the concrete dams' behavior with better performance and less false warnings as a result of better prediction of the extreme values [7]. For air temperature based HT A T models, the time period length of air temperatures is critical to the performance of the models. Based on the experience of existing models [5,25,26], long-term air temperature data can be tried to obtain more reasonable simulation. Therefore, the following variable sets [55] are proposed for temperature effect simulation.
div.formula: = S T T T T T T T T { , ,, , , , , } 1
(30) = = √ó S T T T T T T T T T T T T S T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T { , ,, , , , , , , , , } { , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , } 2
= √ó S T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T { , ,(32)
div.p: where T 0 and T p-q have the same meaning with the variables in Eqs. ( 6) and (7). In Eqs. ( 30)-( 33), S 1 contains the air temperature data of 1/3 year before the observation date of the studied dam response. S 2 , S 3 , S 4 contains the air temperature data of one, two and three years before the observation date, respectively. In this manner, the variable sets using air temperature data of more years before the observation date can be obtained to simulate temperature effect. These temperature variables are adopted together with the hydrostatic and time effect variables {h 1 , h 2 , h 3 , Œ∏, ln(Œ∏ + 1)}. For example, when S 3 is adopted, the variable set for establishing the dam health monitoring model is {h 1 , h 2 , h 3 , T 0 , T 1-2 , T 3-7 , T 8-15 , T 16-30 , T 31-60 , T 61-90 , T 91-120 , T 121-180 , T 181-240 , T 241-300 , T 301-365 , T 366-430 , T 431-490 , T 491-550 , T 551-610 , T 611-670 , T 671-730 , Œ∏, ln (Œ∏ + 1)}.

div.head: Procedure of the proposed model for dam health monitoring
div.p: A traditional multiple linear regression HST model is unable to mine the effect of air temperature on the dam responses accurately. Therefore, Jaya and SSA optimized SVM (LSSVM) models are adopted to establish the forecasting models. When the input is x, the horizontal displacement y(x) of the studied point on the dam can be predicted as Eq. ( 15) by SVM and Eq. ( 23) by LSSVM.

For dam health monitoring modeling problems, different influential factors should be taken into account in different situations. For displacement modeling problems, when harmonic sinusoidal functions are adopted for temperature effect simulation, the input can be a vector as

div.head: = + x h h h sin s cos s sin s sin s cos s ln
div.p: When the air temperature is adopted, take simulation using two years air temperature as an example, the inputs can be a vector as
div.formula: = + x h h h T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T T { , ,, , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ln( 1)
div.p: In Eqs. ( 34)-( 35), T 0 and T p-q has the same meaning with the variables in Eqs. ( 6) and (7). The other variables have the same meaning with the variables in Eq. ( 2)- (5).

Data chosen from the dam health monitoring system are adopted for training the SVM and LSSVM models. Different health monitoring models are evaluated by several performance criteria, such as the mean absolute error (AE mean ), the root mean squared error (RMSE), the maximum absolute error (AE max ) and the coefficient of determination (R 2 ) shown as follows.

div.head: R y i y y i y y i y y i y
div.p: where y D and y ¬ØD represent the simulated values and the average value; y and y ¬Ødenote the measured values and the average value; and N is the number of observations. The optimal model should have the minimum mean absolute error, root mean squared error, maximum absolute error and coefficient of determination close to 1.
The procedure of the proposed approach for dam health monitoring is summarized in the flowchart in Fig. 5 and described in detail as follows:
Step 1: Problem determination. Select the effective factors x and the response variable y.
Step 2: Air temperature data preprocess. Calculate the mean values of segmented air temperature variables according to the selected variable set.

Step 3: Data selection. Collect data from the dam safety monitoring system to build sample sets for the SVM or LSSVM model establishment, including the training sample set and testing sample set. Fig. 5. Flowchart of Jaya optimizer, SSA optimized SVM, LSSVM models for dam behavior prediction.
Step 4: Normalization. The dataset is normalized into the range of [0, 1].
Step 5: Parameter optimization. Optimize the parameters of (leastsquares) support vector machines by Jaya optimizer or SSA according to the description in Section 3.3.

Step 6: Prediction model establishment. The fitting model based on (least-squares) support vector machines is established using the optimized parameters based on the training datasets generated in the previous steps. The prediction equations for horizontal displacement can be calculated as Eq. ( 15) or (23).
Step 7: Generalization verification. Test performance of the obtained prediction model for structural health monitoring using test data to verify the model can perform well on unknown data.
Step 8: Model application. The established model can be adopted for dam behavior prediction.
The flowchart of the proposed model using long-term air temperature and (least-squares) support vector machines for dam health monitoring is illustrated in Fig. 5.

div.head: Data preparation and parameter settings
div.p: The proposed procedure is verified using the monitoring data of a real concrete gravity dam, which was constructed completely in 1953. The maximum height of the dam is 91 m and the length of the dam axis is 1080 m. Fig. 6 shows the upstream and downstream view of the dam. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed approach, the horizontal displacement prediction models of the 32th dam section are studied in the following sections. The dam section is nearly located at the center along the dam axis direction. Water level variations and horizontal displacements of the selected dam section are shown in Fig. 7. The horizontal displacements of the concrete dam were measured early by using the method of tension wire alignment. Until to 1984s, the vacuum laser collimation system was established for measuring displacements. The total length of the collimation line is 1000 m along the axis of the concrete dam [5,55]. The measured mean daily air temperature curve around the dam is shown in Fig. 8. The air temperature is recorded in a meteorological station nearby the dam. The displacement is measured and stored one to three times every month. The water level and mean daily air temperature are measured day by day. The dataset is built over a period from January 1997 to December 2008, which has totally 155 groups of data. The data set in 1997-2006 that contain 126 samples are adopted as the training set, and the data set in 2007-2008 that contain 29 samples are taken as the test set.
According to the multiple linear regression theory, the coefficients of MLR and SR models are estimated using the least squares method.

The parameters of SVM and LSSVM are selected using Jaya optimizer and SSA. Search space of SVM and LSSVM parameters is defined as exponentially growing space. For LSSVM, the search ranges are set as log 10 C ‚àà [0, 5], and log 10 œÉ 2 ‚àà [ -1, 2]. For SVM, the search ranges are set as log 10 C ‚àà [ -1, 3], log 10 Œ≥ ‚àà [ -2, 2], and log 10 Œµ ‚àà [ -4, 0]. For each optimization problem, 50 random runs are performed. The population size is NP = 20 and the maximum number of iterations is 100. Jaya optimizer and SSA is also compared with a popular global optimization algorithm particle swarm optimization (PSO). In PSO, the population size and the number of iterations are set the same as Jaya algorithm, and the other parameter of PSO are set according to the previous study [51]. The results of the proposed approach are also compared with that of the radial basis function networks (RBFN) [55].

div.head: Simulation results of SVM and LSSVM models using harmonic sinusoidal functions
div.p: The performance of the proposed SVM and LSSVM models are firstly tested on harmonic sinusoidal functions based variable set. The results are also compared with that of the multiple linear regression and stepwise regression models. The adopted effective factors for different models are shown in Table 1. Comparison among harmonic sinusoidal functions-based LSSVM models optimized by two objective functions is shown in Table 2. Effect of weights in f 2 (u) on the performance of harmonic sinusoidal functions-based SVM models is shown in Table 3.

From Table 2, it can be seen that by using suitable weights in f 2 (u), better prediction results than that of using f 1 (u) can be obtained. Table 3 shows that the SVM model also can be optimized by using the objective function f 2 (u) with proper weight values. When w 1 ‚àà [0, 0.8] and w 2 = 1 -w 1 , the prediction results are acceptable. The selected representative results for comparison are highlighted in boldface.

The performances of several meta-heuristic algorithms for optimizing LSSVM and SVM parameters are shown in Tables 4 and5. The convergence process curves of three optimization algorithms are shown in Fig. 9. From Table 4 and Fig. 9(a), it can be seen that Jaya and SSA can search for suitable LSSVM parameters as efficiently as the PSO. The accuracy of the three algorithms is the same although Jaya algorithm has no algorithm-specific parameter and has only one update equation. From Table 5 and Fig. 9(b), it can be seen that SSA get slightly more accurate results than Jaya and PSO.

The prediction errors and coefficient of determination of different mathematical models are listed in Table 6. The simulation results and residuals of the MLR, LSSVM and SVM models are illustrated in Figs. 101112, respectively. When harmonic sinusoidal functions are adopted, SVM and LSSVM perform much better than MLR and stepwise regression on both training and test data.

div.head: Simulation results of SVM and LSSVM models using long-term air temperature
div.p: To further improve the performance of dam health monitoring models, temperature effect simulation methods using segmented air temperature data are further study. Some air temperature variable sets are listed in Table 7. In this study, air temperature data for long periods of two to three years is adopted to see whether a long-term air temperature based LSSVM or SVM model is effective. Multiple linear regression models are firstly tested on these variable sets and the results are shown in Table 8. It can be seen that when two-year air temperature data is adopted, the MLR model performs the best. However, it is not performed as well as the harmonic sinusoidal functions based MLR model in term of the test errors.

Then, SVM and LSSVM models are tested on air temperature based variable sets. Comparison among two-year air temperature-based LSSVM models optimized by two objective functions is shown in Table 9. Effect of weights in f 2 (u) on the performance of two-year air temperature-based SVM models is shown in Table 10. From Table 9, it can be seen that by using suitable weights in f 2 (u), similar results can be obtained as using f 1 (u). Table 10 shows that the SVM model also can be optimized by using the objective function f 2 (u) with proper weight values. When w 1 ‚àà [0, 0.8] and w 2 = 1 -w 1 , the prediction results are acceptable. The selected representative results for comparison are highlighted in boldface.

The effect of parameters (C, œÉ 2 ) on cross-validation accuracy of the LSSVM model is shown in Fig. 13. Fig. 14 shows the convergence processes of three algorithms for LSSVM-S 3 parameters optimization when f 1 (u) is adopted. When f 2 (u) is adopted, the accuracy and time of PSO, Jaya and SSA for optimizing LSSVM and SVM parameters are shown in Tables 11 and12. The convergence process curves of three optimization algorithms are illustrated in Fig. 15. From Tables 11 and12, it can be seen that Jaya and SSA are as efficient as PSO on LSSVM

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Variables adopted in different HST models.
Note: The variables in column 1 of the table are defined as that in Eqs. ( 2)-(5).

div.head: Table 2
div.p: Comparison among harmonic sinusoidal functions-based LSSVM models optimized by two objective functions. Note: When f 1 (u) is adopted, the obtained LSSVM parameters are (C, œÉ 2 ) = (1602, 5.8). When f 2 (u) is adopted and the weights are set as (w 1 , w 2 ) = (0.7, 0.3), the obtained LSSVM parameters are (C, œÉ 2 ) = (26,032, 100).
The best results are highlighted in boldface.

parameters search, and they perform more efficiently than PSO on SVM parameters selection. The accuracy of the three algorithms is the same although Jaya and SSA have no algorithm-specific parameter. From Figs. 14 and 15, it can be seen that three optimization algorithms converge quickly to select model parameters when air temperature variable sets are adopted. Performances of SVM and LSSVM using different variable sets (S 1 -S 4 ) are shown in Tables 131415. With the increase of air temperature data adopted, the errors reduce dramatically. When two years data of air temperature is adopted, the prediction results are the best. The phenomenon is the same with the air temperature based MLR models. But the prediction results of SVM and LSSVM models are much better than MLR models when long-term air temperature are adopted to simulate the dam behavior. The prediction errors of the model using S 3 are obviously smaller than that of the model using S 1 and S 2 . Although the training error of the S 4 model is smaller than that of S 3 model, the test error of S 3 is the smallest. Therefore, S 3 is adopted as the representative variable set of long-term air temperature variables in the following studies. Through numerical experiments, 2-year air temperature data before the dam response measurement can obtain ideal results and adding more air temperature has no significant accuracy improvement. The suitable time period (one year, two years, three or more years) is related to the massiveness of the dam and the dam types. For other dams, suitable time periods of air temperature data need further experiments on actual monitoring data of the specific dam.

Performance comparison among mathematical models using two years air temperature is given in Table 16. The machine learning techniques RBFN, LSSVM and SVM obtained much smaller errors than the MLR model. The optimized SVM model performs the best compared with the other mathematical models. The prediction results and residuals of the LSSVM-S 3 and SVM-S 3 models are shown in Figs. 16 and17. The LSSVM-S 3 and SVM-S 3 models can fit the measured displacement better than MLR-HST model, and the residuals are also much reduced.

div.head: Direct comparative studies of different models 4.4.1. Comparison among MLR-HST, LSSVM-HST and LSSVM-S 3

The best results are highlighted in boldface.

The best results are highlighted in boldface. Note: Temperature variables are adopted together with the hydrostatic and time effect variables {h 1 , h 2 , h 3 , Œ∏}. For example, when S 1 is adopted, the variable set for establishing the model is {h 1 , h 2 , h 3 , T 0 , T 1-2 , T 3-7 , T 8-15 , T 16-30 , T 31-60 , T 61-90 , T 91-120 , Œ∏}. Note: When f 1 (u) is adopted, the obtained LSSVM parameters are (C, œÉ 2 ) = (1068.2, 3.573). The best results are highlighted in boldface.
HT A T (S 3 ) model has the smallest prediction errors and residuals.

div.head: Comparison among MLR-HST, SVM-HST and SVM-S 3
div.p: The results of the air temperature based SVM-S 3 model and the harmonic sinusoidal functions based MLR-HST model are compared in The diagram in Fig. 20 clearly shows prediction errors of three approaches. Prediction residuals of different models are compared in Fig. 21. The proposed SVM based HT A T (S 3 ) model has the smallest prediction errors and residuals. Therefore, the propose approach can dramatically improve the performance of HST models in prediction accuracy and less false warnings as a result of better prediction of the extreme values.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: To improve the prediction accuracy of existing dam behavior prediction models, long-term air temperature data based HT A T models are proposed for dam health monitoring. Compared with the traditional HST model, only air temperature data are added to make more precise predictions for dam responses. LSSVM and SVM techniques are applied to mine the temperature effect from the measured air temperature of a The best results are highlighted in boldface.

div.head: Table 14
div.p: Performance of LSSVM models obtained by using objective function f 2 (u) with w 1 = w 2 = 0.5. The best results are highlighted in boldface.

div.head: Table 15
div.p: Performance of SVM models obtained by using objective function f 2 (u) with w 1 = 0.7 and w 2 = 0.3. The best results are highlighted in boldface.

div.head: Table 16
div.p: Comparison among mathematical models using two years air temperature data. The best results are highlighted in boldface. long period. The novel Jaya optimizer and SSA can solve the parameter optimization problem well. Both of them are convenient to implement, and SSA shows slightly accurate in SVM parameter optimization problem. A real concrete dam is taken as an example to verify the proposed approach. Compared with harmonic sinusoidal functions based models, the long-term air temperature based SVM and LSSVM models using two years data can obtain the best performance. Forecasting accuracy is much improved considering several errors are much reduced. Therefore, the proposed SVM (LSSVM) based HT A T model can reflect the effect of real temperature variations on the structural response.

Mata et al. [7] proposed a successful HTT model with better performance than HST models. The measured temperatures of the dam body were involved in the modeling directly and PCA is adopted to find statistically significant temperature observations for the proposed functional model. For the PCA, a subjective step should be employed to define a number of principal components. Numerical results confirm the statement that the proposed HT A T model can perform better than HST models. Comparison between HST and HTT was presented, so this study is surely a step forward from the HST-model.

Although there are a high number of variables in the proposed model, there is no computational burden or special requirement considering the number of training samples is not very large. The simulation was programmed using MATLAB and performed on a computer equipped with an Intel Xeon E5, 2.40 GHz processor and 16GB RAM.

The proposed approach is tested on a concrete gravity dam and it is strongly recommended to test this method on concrete arch dams in the future. We expect similar results since the displacements are within a similar range as for concrete dams [7,22] and expose similar correlation to the (air) temperature.
